summary: This document is a series of internal email exchanges from November 12, 2020, between the FBI and DOJ regarding media attention on the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. It discusses a planned briefing for victims, a draft DOJ press statement, and concerns about news articles and potential witness identity disclosures in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

persons.name: Stacie
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who was spoken to regarding a draft press statement from the DOJ about the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Amy Thorenson
persons.context: Copied on an email about media attention regarding the FBI's briefing on the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the FBI probe whose findings are being discussed for sharing with victims.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to a court deadline concerning the potential release of witness identities in her case.

events.title: FBI/DOJ Media Coordination on Epstein Probe
events.description: Internal emails discuss media plans, a draft DOJ press statement, and a meeting to brief victims in Miami on the findings of the Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

events.title: NY Post Article on FBI Briefing
events.description: The NY Post publishes an article stating the FBI is hosting a briefing to share findings of the Jeffrey Epstein probe with victims.

events.title: Potential Release of Maxwell Witness Identities
events.description: A Miami Herald story suggests a court deadline passed, potentially leading to the release of witness identities in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.

keyFacts: On November 12, 2020, the FBI and DOJ were coordinating a media response and a victim briefing regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation findings.
A draft DOJ press statement was prepared for potential release that day.
News media (NY Post, Miami Herald) had reported on the FBI's victim briefing and a potential disclosure of witness identities in the Ghislaine Maxwell case.
The FBI Victim Services Division and public affairs offices were actively managing communications about the sensitive probe.
